Also fails w/ JDK 6.0 Release

The current line coverage is using the JVMPI interfaces to collect execution information. Starting with java 5 when the JVMTI had become available we have experienced a few problems while using JVMPI.
JVMPI has been completely removed in java 6 so the line coverage is not expected to run with this version

As a workaround can you try to run line coverage using java 4 ?

Sorry, not able to run w/ Java 4.  The code I'm testing requires Java 5.  I tried to run w/ Java 4, but tests failed due to various issues probably resulting from the fact that the classes in my plugins could not be loaded by Java 1.4.  Stack traces follow:

Also confirmed that it does not run w/ Java 6.  Console message follows:
> FATAL ERROR: JVMPI, an experimental interface, is no longer supported.
> Please use the supported interface: the JVM Tool Interface (JVM TI).
> For information on temporary workarounds contact: jvmpi_eol@sun.com

okay..

I hate to ask people to change settings but can you try one more thing to see if you can get rid of your exceptions you get when you run with java 4 :

Can you go to Windows>Preferences > Java > Compiler 
In the Compiler Compliance level combo select 1.4; 
I assume you have 1.5
As long as you don't use java 5 specific features this will allow you to run with java 4

(In reply to comment #5)
> okay..
> I hate to ask people to change settings but can you try one more thing to see
> if you can get rid of your exceptions you get when you run with java 4 :
> Can you go to Windows>Preferences > Java > Compiler 
> In the Compiler Compliance level combo select 1.4; 

I could do that, but it does not help the production case since the plugins being tested *and* the test suite itself use annotations and require 1.5.



> I assume you have 1.5

Yes.

> As long as you don't use java 5 specific features this will allow you to run
> with java 4

The plugins being tested do use 1.5 specific features.  Primarily annotations.  In addition, the JUnit test suite itself uses annotations.
No resources available to cover this in 4.4; moving to future
Pity about this problem.  Would have saved some grief if the download page for this had clearly stated that it doesn't work with Java 5.
EclEmma (http://eclemma.org/userdoc/coverageview.html), although a little buggy, seems to fill similar functionality with Java 5 for those looking for JUnit code coverage statistics.
